elements.text: PART ONE
SCENE 1: EXT. LONDON STREET, 1944
RAID SIRENS.
OFF, ARP WARDEN OPENS UP AIR RAID SHELTER — PADLOCK AND CHAIN, HEAVY METAL GATES.
OPEN. FOOTSTEPS ON STREET AS PEOPLE MOVE TOWARDS AIR RAID SHELTER AND HEAD DOWN STEPS INSIDE.
(MUTTERINGS, AS THEY ENTER AND GO DOWN STEPS) Come on./ Jerry's back./
Get inside./
Hope it’s not long this time. [ETC]
(OFF, CALLING) This way to the shelter. Nice and easy down the stairs. Don’t run! You know the drill.
SCENE 2: EXT. OUTSIDE AIR RAID SHELTER, LONDON STREET
CONTINUOUS
ONGOING. LAST FEW PEOPLE MOVING OFF DOWN THE STAIRS INSIDE THE AIR RAID SHELTER.
WARDEN STARTS PULLING GATES CLOSED — THEN STOPS, SEEING KINVAR.
(CALLING) Oi! Lad! What are you doing over there?
FAR DISTANCE, GERMAN PLANES APPROACH UNDER FOLLOWING.
HURRIES ALONG STREET.
(APPROACHING) Where is everyone going?
You know the drill. All residents are advised to enter the air raid shelter when the sirens sound. (BEAT) Do I know you? Ain’t seen you round here before...
(GETTING AGITATED) I don’t understand. What is happening?
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 3
Jerry's coming, that’s what’s happening. What’s the matter with you, lad? You just dropped out of the sky?
CRACKLING AND FIZZING IN THE AIR AS VILAL START TO MANIFEST,
OFF.
No, no, no. They’re coming again. They’re coming for me.

Them Luftwaffe ain’t too choosy. They’re coming for everyone. V-1 rockets. That’s why we’ve got to get off the streets. (HURRIES INSIDE SHELTER, EFFORT AS HE PULLS GATES CLOSED) Come down the shelter, it’1l be safe down there.
Nowhere is safe! I can’t be here. Not here. Not now. (STARTS
AWAY)
So be it, lad. I can’t force you. I got dozens of folk down
here relying on me. I can’t chase after one stray. (EFFORT)
(GOING OFF) I’1l look after myself. I just need to get away!
WARDEN PULLS GATES FULLY CLOSED. HEADS UNDERGROUND.
(CALLING AFTER) Get yourself to a cellar, lad! (GOING OFF, GRUMBLING TO SELF) I don’t know, you try and help folk...
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 4
SCENE 3: EXT. ANOTHER LONDON STREET
FIZZING AND CRACKLING BECOMES LOUDER AS HALF A DOZEN VILAL
MATERIALISE FULLY. THEY STOMP ABOUT IN HEAVY ARMOUR.
PLANES FLY PAST OVERHEAD, STARTING TO DROP BOMBS UNDER FOLLOWING.
(DISTORTED BY HEMLET) What is this place?
SCANNING WITH CLUNKY TECHNOLOGY.
(DISTORTED BY HELMET) Earth, General. A warzone.
SOUNDS ON SCANNER.
(D) An alert. From the vortex ship. They report resources are down to the red zone.
(D) Then we must hurry. We will not have the power to remain here for long.
START STOMPING ALONG STREET. Vl ROCKETS HIT NEARBY. EXPLOSION.
(D) These are impressive weapons for such primitives. Which way is the trace?
CAPTAIN STOMPS OFF, USING SCANNER.
(D) This way, General.
(D) Then take a squad and follow it.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 5
SCENE 4: EXT. OUTSIDE AIR RAID SHELTER, LONDON STREET
STOMP UP AND RATTLE AIR RAID SHELTER GATES.
(DISTORTED BY HELMET) Here. Some sort of cage. We should try to gain entry.
RATTLE GATES AGAIN. ARP WARDEN HURRIES UP STAIRS FROM
BELOW.
(CALLING, OFF, HURRYING UP STAIRS) Oi! Them gates are government property! Get away. (ARRIVING INSIDE GATES) You can’t do- (BREAKS OFF) Lumme. What in heaven’s name are you lot? Like walking tanks!
(DISTORTED BY HELMET) Where is the fugitive?
You what? Is there someone inside there?
(DISTORTED BY HELMET) Visors up!
RAISED ON VILAL WARRIOR HELMETS.
The Vilal are inside here.
Your faces... What’s wrong with them? (TERRIFIED, BUT MAKING A STAND) I.. I dunno what you want or where you came from. But if you don’t get away from these gates- (DRAWS REVOLVER)
The human has a weapon.
I have. And I’m not afraid to-
ZAP OF VILAL WEAPONRY. ARP WARDEN IS VAPORISED.
CRIES OUT
Kinvar is not here. Inform the General. We return to the vortex
ship and assess.
STOMP OFF AND FIZZ BACK INTO VORTEX.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 6
MUSIC SEGUE, TIME PASSES.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 7
SCENE 5: EXT. CONSTANCE’S STREET
A QUIET LONDON SUBURB. EARLY MORNING BIRDS CHEEP. A MILKMAN WHISTLES, PLACING BOTTLES IN A CRATE. HORSEDRAWN MILK FLOAT
OFF, BOTTLES CHINKING.
MATERIALISES. DOORS OPEN. DOCTOR AND CONSTANCE STEP OUT.
(LOCKING TARDIS) You’re certain this is what you want, Constance? The time and place you wish to be?
(WALKING ON) Yes, Doctor. I’ve neglected my duties for far too long.
THEY WALK ALONG PATH THROUGH FOLLOWING.
(AFTER A FEW PACES) What happened with Ammar-
(INTERRUPTS, SLIGHTLY TOO INSISTENT) -has no bearing upon my decision whatsoever. I’ve simply judged it high time I put my affairs in order.
THEY WALK ON AND CONSTANCE TAKES OUT HER KEYS.
This one is ours. Please. Do come in.
OPENS GARDEN GATE AND LEADS DOCTOR UP PATH TO FRONT
UNDER FOLLOWING.
Would you like me to stay?
I shall make you a cup of tea, at least. So long as you don’t mind powdered milk.
Well, thank you. For inviting me into your home.
PUTS KEYS IN DOOR AND UNLOCKS.
by Matt Fitton (003-—AB edits) Page 8
SCENE 6: INT. HALLWAY, CONSTANCE’S HOUSE
DOOR UNLOCKED AND OPENS, PUSHING PILE OF POST.
(OUTSIDE DOOR) Since I’ve been enjoying your hospitality all this time, it seems only fair I return the favour. (ENTERING) Dear me. How long has it been?
You’ve built up quite the pile of correspondence. Almost as bad as the TARDIS mailbox. (BEAT) Thank you for sorting that out, by the way.
HELPS CONSTANCE PICK UP LETTERS. SHE SORTS THROUGH THEM.

Letters. Postcards. (READING CARDS) I seem to have missed delivery of an urgent telegram message. Every morning for the past week. (TO DOCTOR) Well, according to the postmarks, it is still 1944 at least!
I did my best. We should have arrived back just a few weeks after we were last here. Or first here. A suitable distance. I wasn’t sure if you-
(WALKING ON) Don’t you worry about that, Doctor. Come through.
FOLLOWS CONSTANCE THROUGH TO KITCHEN.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 9
SCENE 7: INT. KITCHEN, CONSTANCE’S HOUSE (CONTINUOUS)
THEY ENTER KITCHEN. CONSTANCE PICKS UP A KETTLE AND FILLS IT AT THE TAP.
Do make yourself at home.
Thank you. Given your hurried departure, I wasn’t sure if you’d prefer to return to Bletchley, [or-]
(INTERRUPTS) Here suits me best.
LIGHTS STOVE AND PLACES KETTLE ON HOB. THEN BUSTLES
ROOM.
Sometimes, one feels the need for home comforts around one. Kettle on. Now. (RUNS FINGER ALONG TABLE) I can see I’1l need to get my duster out.
It’s a very tidy house.
Not to my eye. (STOPPING) Things go to ruin even when one does nothing.
(BEAT) That’s entropy for you...
SILENCE.
Are you sure you won’t [reconsider? ]
(INTERRUPTS) Quite, quite sure.
Well, then. Perhaps I won’t stay. Goodbyes are not really my forte.
Tea would have been nice, but... as you see fit, Doctor Smith.
‘Doctor Smith’? We’ve no need to be so formal, have we? After all our time together-
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 10
(OVER HIM) I’m sure you have things to be getting on with. (HOLDS OUT HAND) Thank you. I don’t mean to seem ungrateful. But I’ve been away too long.
(SHAKES HAND) Thank you, Mrs Clarke. For everything. You’ve been an exemplary travelling companion.
Now, don’t disrupt that filing system I’ve put in place. You might stand a chance of actually attending to some of your correspondence at last.
I look forward to reviewing my post. And you have your own to deal with. That should keep you busy. For a while at least...
AWKWARD PAUSE.
Doctor. Wait. Despite what you might think, this is not easy for me. I don’t do this lightly. I... (TAILS OFF)

(SIGH) You’re as bad at this as I am. Tell you what, let’s not formalise your resignation just yet. Why don’t I give you a moment? You’ve some magnificent blooms by the front door. Rosa muchata. Might I take a cutting, to remember you by?
For the TARDIS garden? That would be.. nice. Please, be my guest.
Then I’1l just let the water boil. The pot can brew. (WALKS OFF
HALLWAY) I’1l be back before tick turns to tock!
SCENE 8: EXT OUTSIDE CONSTANCE’S HOUSE (CONTINUOUS)
EXITS AND CLOSES FRONT DOOR.
SIGH) Ah. Constance. My constant companion no more. (BEAT
Perhaps it’s for the best if I make the break for us both.
WALKS ALONG PATH, THROUGH GARDEN GATE, CLOSING IT BEHIND, THEN OFF ALONG STREET.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 11
SCENE 9: INT. KITCHEN, CONSTANCE’S HOUSE.
SORTS THROUGH LETTERS.
My, my. A few weeks? It looks rather more like a few months.
GOES TO WINDOW.
And in the garden... Autumn leaves. It has been months! Oh, Doctor... (SIGHS)
LETTERS DOWN ON TABLE. SEARCHES CUPBOARDS FOR CUPS.
Months. So almost a year since the last time I filled this kettle. The last time I cooked a breakfast on this stove.
STOPS HER ACTIVITY.
(MUFFLED, CALLING, IN DREAMLIKE ECHO OF FLASHBACK) Constance?
Is the toast done?
(AS VOICEOVER) The last time.. I saw you.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 12
SCENE 10: INT. KITCHEN, CONSTANCE’S HOUSE [FLASHBACK]
ATMOS. RADIO ON, 1943 OR EARLIER-STYLE MUSIC. CONSTANCE
PLATES ON TABLE. PULLS GRILL OUT FROM STOVE.
(CALLING) Your toast is ready Henry! Almost ruined.
(VOICEOVER) Just how you like it.
SCRAPES TOAST, THEN PUTS SLICES ON PLATE.
HURRIES IN.
Have you seen my socks? I never take enough socks.
I’ll do it. You eat your breakfast.
EXITS TO HALL.
(CALLING) Everything else is packed! My kitbag’s tied up and ready to go. Just leave them by the side, darling!
GOES UPSTAIRS.
(CALLING, OFF) What would you do without me, Henry?
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 13
SCENE 11: INT. BEDROOM, CONSTANCE’S HOUSE [FLASHBACK]
MUSIC ON RADIO CONTINUES, OFF, IN KITCHEN DOWNSTAIRS. CONSTANCE
RIFLES IN HENRY’S KITBAG.
(SOTTO) Socks by the side. But I’1l pop a little special something else inside to surprise you...
(VOICEOVER) Chocolate. Acquired when the Bletchley quartermaster wasn’t looking.
(SOTTO) (STOPS, FINDING SOMETHING) Oh.
RUSTLES IN KITBAG.
PULLS UP OUTSIDE. HONKS HORN.
(CALLING, FROM KITCHEN) Darling? It looks like Ginger’s here with the car.
PULLS A LETTER FROM KITBAG.
(CALLING) Shan’t be a moment! (EXAMINES ENVELOPE, READING) ‘My
Dearest H’?
(VO) That’s not my writing.
SNIFFS
(VO) Nor my scent.
EXITS KITCHEN AND COMES ALONG HALL, OFF DOWNSTAIRS.
STUFFS LETTER BACK IN KITBAG AND TIES TOP.
(CALLING) I’m just about ready for the off.
COMES UP STAIRS. CONSTANCE FINISHES TYING KITBAG.
(ENTERING) I think I have everything.
PASSES HIM HIS BAG AND SOCKS SEPARATELY.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 14
Your bag, Henry. And your socks.
Are you all right, darling?
Oh... You know. The usual. I’m never sure exactly when you might be-

(OVER HER) Hush now. We both know, it is how it is. I’1l be overseas with naval intelligence. That’s all I can say. You go and look after your girls at Wavendon. The time will fly by while I’m away. All that marching up and down and whatever else they have you doing there. Filing, typing, translations. It all helps, I’m sure.
And then, who knows, this beastly war may be six months closer to being over?
Indeed. I’11 do my best to let you know when I might be coming back.
HONK OUTSIDE. HENRY PECKS CONSTANCE ON CHEEK.
Remain constant, Constance. My rock.
You too, Henry. Be safe.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 15
SCENE 12: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
FLICKS SWITCHES. PULLS LEVERS.
Goodbyes are most definitely not my strong suit. Simpler by far to slip away. But where t— [-—o?] (BREAKS OFF) Ah, of course!
PICKS UP FILE OF LETTERS. FLICKS THROUGH.
All my unattended post. Unanswered, unacted upon. Filed and indexed in order of priority. Thank you, Mrs Clarke. (PULLS OUT
CARD) Oh, and here’s that wedding invitation. What’s this you’ve written? (READING) ‘Respond or attend — it’s only polite!’ (SIGHS) It’s all so very black and white to you, Constance...
OUTSIDE TARDIS.
(GROANS) Oh no. No doubt some member of the public mistaking this for a real police box!
LOUDER. DOCTOR ACTIVATES TARDIS MONITOR.
(MUFFLED, OUTSIDE) Doctor! Please!
Now, who are you? There’s something not quite human about the hair...
A BUZZING OUTSIDE AS KINVAR TRIES TO PICK LOCK. TARDIS BEEPS IN ALARM.
Oh. Trying to pick her locks, eh? The TARDIS doesn’t like that.
(CALLING, OUTSIDE) Let me in! Doctor! Doctor, I know it must be you!
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 16
SCENE 13: EXT. STREET, OUTSIDE TARDIS
OPENS TARDIS.
(CALLS) Please step away from the doors, thank you very much!
(STEPPING BACK) At last. Please. You must help me!
(STEPPING OUT) Must I? First of all, I’d like to know how you know who I am.
CLOSES DOOR AND LOCKS IT BEHIND HIM.
And what were you doing to my TARDIS? Attempted breaking and entering? Back away. Back right away!
STEPS FURTHER AWAY.
Sorry. Sorry. I’m desperate. That’s all.
STEPS CLOSER.
Desperate? I can see that. And desperate people do desperate things.
FIZZING IN THE AIR STARTS. KINVAR PANICS AND MAKES A GRAB FOR THE DOCTOR’S COAT POCKETS.
Oh no. They’re coming. (SCUFFLING WITH DOCTOR) Where’s your key?! We’ve got to go!
THEY SCUFFLE, INVITATION FALLS TO FLOOR.
(SCUFFLING WITH KINVAR) Please! Manhandling my person and picking my pockets is not the way to win my confidence!
I’m not from this world. I’ve been looking for you. They’re
coming! They’re coming for me.
AS VILAL MATERIALISE A LITTLE WAY OFF.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 17
Ah. Heavily armoured. Heavily armed. Perhaps we are better inside, after all.
HASTILY UNLOCKS TARDIS.
I’m sorry, Doctor. Sorry for grabbing you. Oh. You dropped letter!
END OF PREVIOUS, VILAL START STOMPING TOWARDS THEM.
Never mind that now. Come on!
GRABS KINVAR AND THEY HURRY INSIDE, CLOSING DOOR.
(ARRIVING) He is here. Inside this box.
off
your
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 18
SCENE 14: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
ALARMS BEEP. THE DOCTOR HURRIEDLY ADJUSTS CONTROLS.
Yes. I knew it. I knew you would help.
You didn’t give me much choice! And you still haven’t answered my question. How do you know who I am?
WEAPON BLAST OUTSIDE TARDIS.
Goodness me. Aren’t they even going to knock?
(OUTSIDE) Hear us. We want the fugitive.
Fugitive, eh? Well, I’ve never been one to ignore someone running away from a heavily armed militia.
Don’t let them take me. Please.
And you have found me with something of a window in my schedule...
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 19
SCENE 15: EXT. STREET, OUTSIDE TARDIS
BLAST TARDIS AGAIN. VILAL SCANNER ‘LOW POWER’ ALERT AS BEFORE.
Resources critical.
GENERAL STOMPS FORWARD TO EXAMINE TARDIS.
Our weapons have had no effect. Recharge the power packs.
HUM OF RECHARGING WEAPON.
(VIA SPEAKERS) Not today, thank you.
(OFF, VIA SPEAKERS) Make them go away!
(VIA SPEAKERS) This young man is terrified. I’d like to know why.
He is needed. You must give him up.

(VIA SPEAKERS) Must I? I never respond well to being told what I ‘must’ do. We are staying right here until one of you explains. And as you will discover, my TARDIS is a much more impregnable prospect than she first appears.
Fire weapons!
WEAPON BLASTS TARDIS, TO NO EFFECT.
(VIA SPEAKERS) Molecular disruptor beams? You’1l have to do a lot better than that.
Examine the box. All sides! There must be a clue to its nature.
STOMP ABOUT. VILAL COMMUNICATION ALERT.
(APPROACHING) Urgent communication from the vortex ship, General. Systems critical. Incoming message.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 20
DISTORTION OF THE ZERITH SIGNAL.
(VIA SPEAKERS) What’s going on out there?
(TO VILAL CAPTAIN) It is the enemy. They taunt us once again.
(D, VIA COMMUNICATOR) You run, Vilal cowards. But we will seek you out, wherever you hide.
Have they found our location?
Not yet, General. This is a general transmission on all our
frequencies.
(D) We will eradicate you. The Zerith are coming!
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 21
SCENE 16: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
ALARMS BEEP. THE DOCTOR HURRIEDLY ADJUSTS CONTROLS, TRYING TO TUNE INTO ZERITH SIGNAL.
(DISTORTED, UNINTELLIGIBLE, LINES FROM SCENE 15) You run, Vilal cowards. But we will seek you out, wherever you hide. (PAUSE) We will eradicate you. The Zerith are coming!
What is happening?
Another signal from the ether. Something that’s got our troll- like friends in a tizzy.
MONITOR, OUTSIDE TARDIS, VILAL STOMP OFF AND START FIZZING
INTO VORTEX.
Look at the monitor. I think they’re leaving.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 22
SCENE 17: INT. KITCHEN, CONSTANCE’S HOUSE
BOILS AND WHISTLES. CONSTANCE POURS WATER INTO TEAPOT.
SITS AT KITCHEN TABLE, SLICES AN ENVELOPE WITH LETTER OPENER, AND UNFOLDS PAPER INSIDE.
(TO SELF) Thank you, Director. Three months’ leave from Bletchley was just the ticket. Though I’m afraid I may have ended up taking slightly longer.
LETTER DOWN. PICKS UP ANOTHER ENVELOPE.
KNOCK AT THE FRONT DOOR, OFF.
(TO SELF) Back so soon, Doctor? It’s hardly had time to brew.
GETS UP FROM CHAIR AND WALKS TO HALLWAY. ANOTHER
KNOCK.
(CALLING, GOING OFF INTO HALLWAY) Just coming!
DOOR BEING UNLOCKED, OFF.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 23
SCENE 18: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
SCANS AND BLEEPS.
Have they gone?

I think so. (CHECKING CONSOLE) The only movement out there for the last ten minutes has been a messenger boy on his bike. And several pigeons. That strange communication sent your pursuers scurrying back to their ship. (CHECKING TARDIS READOUTS) Concealed in the vortex, just on the edge of local spacetime. Interesting technology. Hmm. I’d like to know who they are. But we should probably start with your name, young man.
Kinvar. I am Kinvar. They are the Vilal.
Vilal? Can’t say I’m familiar with them. And they’ve certainly never come across a TARDIS before. But you seem to know me.
I don’t ‘know you’ exactly. I only know about you. That you were here. In the countryside, a few months ago. I detected this wonderful machine. Then she vanished.
I’m sure my TARDIS appreciates the compliment. But we don’t tend to stay put for long. Bletchley was an exception.
That’s right. Bletchley. I got there too late. You’d gone. Eventually I worked out you’d left with a ‘Mrs Clarke’. I thought she might come back, so I found her house. I kept watch over it. I met-
You’ve been spying on me?
I made contact with the local authorities. I think they’re called ‘S.I.S’.
You’ve been in touch with the Secret Intelligence Service?
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 24

I thought that they could help. I had little to offer them... but I’d no need of it any more. They seemed excited at first. Talking about technological breakthroughs... But they didn’t really know much about you. Or your Ship. Then they became rather insistent.. I thought it best to get away.
Kinvar, what have you done?
I traded... some of my technology for information. About you.

What?! Your technology has no business on Earth. Especially not now. This war is coming to an end. The last thing the planet needs is for it to start up again, with an arms race no-one has any hope of winning. (ANGRY) Of all the irresponsible idiocy!
I’m sorry.
And if you came here on the trail of Mrs Clarke, then your armoured friends could know about her too.
ACTIVATES DOOR CONTROL.
What are you doing? We can’t go out there!
Come, or stay behind. I don’t care. But I do want to make sure my friend is safe.
EXITS.
(CALLING, OUTSIDE) And if you do stay in there, don’t touch anything!
CLOSE.
(TO SELF) I’m sorry. I’m sorry. I just don’t want to fight.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 25
SCENE 19: INT. VILAL SHIP
HUMMING, CLUNKING & FAILING TECHNOLOGY.
Report Captain.
The enemy are running long range vortex scans. It is only a matter of time before they identify our spacetime location.
Did we find out anything about the blue box?
No General. But we did find this. The pilot - this ‘Doctor’ — may have dropped it outside. (HANDS INVITATION CARD TO VILAL
(TURNS OVER CARD) A primitive communication? Not the key, then.
No. But it may be a key. There is biodata on this paper. Some too complex for our analysis.
The Doctor’s?
We think so. There is also a human trace. They may also know about the box.
GENERAL ACTIVATES CONTROLS.
Then locate it. Commence scans for this biodata and for Kinvar!
It appears that entering that vessel has removed him from local spacetime.
Divert all remaining power to the vortex scanner. Kinvar cannot stay inside that thing forever. He must emerge at some point. And we must find him!
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 26
SCENE 20: INT. KITCHEN, CONSTANCE’S HOUSE
DOOR OPENS AND CLOSES, OFF. DOCTOR HURRIES IN ALONG HALL.
STILL BOILING DRY, WHISTLING.
(CALLING IN HALL) Only me! I’m sorry to barge back in, Mrs Clarke, but our goodbyes have been rudely interrupted. (ENTERING KITCHEN, TAKING KETTLE OFF HEAT) Goodness, this has almost boiled dry.
KETTLE IN SINK. IT HISSES.

(CARRIES ON REGARDLESS) Yes. I’m afraid we have an alien interloper on our hands. And he has some rather unsavoury heavies on his tail. It may be wise if we delay our parting until- (BREAKS OFF, REALISING CONSTANCE HASN’T SAID A WORD) Mrs Clarke? Is everything all right?
(DEEP BREATH) Not really, Dr Smith.
Constance. Have you been crying?
No. (GATHERING HERSELF) Yes. Sorry. Alien interloper, you say. Of course.
He can wait. What is it, Mrs Clarke? Has something happened?
You might say that. That undelivered telegram was delivered.
PUSHES TELEGRAM ACROSS TABLE. THE DOCTOR PICKS IT UP.
From the War Office. (READING) ‘Deeply regret to inform you’- (BREAKS OFF) Oh no.
Lieutenant Commander Henry Clarke. Lost in action. Two weeks ago. Classified operations. They can’t even tell me where it was that he- (STOPS HERSELF)
Constance.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 27
I think I knew. I think I knew that I’d lost him long before he
went away.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 28
SCENE 21: INT. BEDROOM, CONSTANCE’S HOUSE [FLASHBACK]
FOLLOWING ON FROM FLASHBACK SCENE 11. FRONT DOOR CLOSES. CAR
OUTSIDE.
OPENS WINDOW.
(OUTSIDE, CALLING) Goodbye, darling!
(CALLING) Goodbye!
DRIVES AWAY. CONSTANCE WAITS A MOMENT, THEN CLOSES WINDOW.
ACROSS ROOM, OPENS WARDROBE, PULLS OUT CLOTHES, SEARCHING.
(TO SELF) How long, Henry? How long has this been going on?
STARTS PULLING OUT DRAWERS. A STASH OF LETTERS FALLS
UNDERNEATH ONE OF THE DRAWERS.
(GASPS) No. No.
PICKS UP LETTERS.
(READING LETTER) ‘My darling H. How many weeks until we meet again?’ (THROWS DOWN LETTER) No! Who is she? How could you, Henry? How could you?
UP ANOTHER.
(STEELS HERSELF WITH A BREATH, AND READS) ‘Every time we part,
I die a little. I await you now, on the platform. Every time we have met through this terrible conflict, you have brought hope
into my life...
(OVERLAPPING CONSTANCE) -you have brought hope into my life. Some small hope that one day, this war will end. And that we can be together.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 29
SCENE 22: EXT. TRAIN PLATFORM, VIENNA [FLASHBACK]
PULLS INTO PLATFORM. CROWDS BUSTLING. HENRY HURRIES ALONG PLATFORM.
(ARRIVING) Ana! Ana.
Henry. I have you for how long this time?
THEY WALKING ALONG PLATFORM TOGETHER, SPEAKING CLOSELY.
A few months. Until we’ve secured certain routes and certain people from the east.
The Russian bear keeps roaring. The Axis is stalled. But it means more people than ever are fleeing through the hills and the forests. From Hungary, Poland, Romania. From my own Bucharest.
I know. We can assist. There are some names I’ve been asked to look out for. Scientists, officials.
And who is helping me this time?

Mr Harry Cook. Trader in fine linens. I have all the relevant papers. While I’m here, I’m officially a civilian. So I suppose technically, that makes you my commanding officer. I must obey your every order.
(STOPPING) In that case, Mr Cook, I order you to kiss me.
And I am happy to comply.
THEY EMBRACE AND KISS. PEOPLE PASS ON THE PLATFORM.
WHISTLE BLOWS SEVERAL TIMES. IT STARTS TO MOVE OFF, STEAM
AROUND THEM.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 30
SCENE 23: INT. KITCHEN, CONSTANCE’S HOUSE

DOCTOR: Look at the monitor. I think they’re leaving.
QUICKSILVER: by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 22
QUICKSILVER: SCENE 17: INT. KITCHEN, CONSTANCE’S HOUSE
KETTLE: BOILS AND WHISTLES. CONSTANCE POURS WATER INTO TEAPOT.
SHE: SITS AT KITCHEN TABLE, SLICES AN ENVELOPE WITH LETTER OPENER, AND UNFOLDS PAPER INSIDE.
CONSTANCE: (TO SELF) Thank you, Director. Three months’ leave from Bletchley was just the ticket. Though I’m afraid I may have ended up taking slightly longer.
PUTS: LETTER DOWN. PICKS UP ANOTHER ENVELOPE.
PUTS: KNOCK AT THE FRONT DOOR, OFF.
CONSTANCE: (TO SELF) Back so soon, Doctor? It’s hardly had time to brew.
CONSTANCE: GETS UP FROM CHAIR AND WALKS TO HALLWAY. ANOTHER
URGENT: KNOCK.
CONSTANCE: (CALLING, GOING OFF INTO HALLWAY) Just coming!
FRONT: DOOR BEING UNLOCKED, OFF.
QUICKSILVER: by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 23
QUICKSILVER: SCENE 18: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
TARDIS: SCANS AND BLEEPS.
KINVAR: Have they gone?
DOCTOR: I think so. (CHECKING CONSOLE) The only movement out there for the last ten minutes has been a messenger boy on his bike. And several pigeons. That strange communication sent your pursuers scurrying back to their ship. (CHECKING TARDIS READOUTS) Concealed in the vortex, just on the edge of local spacetime. Interesting technology. Hmm. I’d like to know who they are. But we should probably start with your name, young man.
KINVAR: Kinvar. I am Kinvar. They are the Vilal.
DOCTOR: Vilal? Can’t say I’m familiar with them. And they’ve certainly never come across a TARDIS before. But you seem to know me.
KINVAR: I don’t ‘know you’ exactly. I only know about you. That you were here. In the countryside, a few months ago. I detected this wonderful machine. Then she vanished.
DOCTOR: I’m sure my TARDIS appreciates the compliment. But we don’t tend to stay put for long. Bletchley was an exception.
KINVAR: That’s right. Bletchley. I got there too late. You’d gone. Eventually I worked out you’d left with a ‘Mrs Clarke’. I thought she might come back, so I found her house. I kept watch over it. I met-
DOCTOR: You’ve been spying on me?
KINVAR: I made contact with the local authorities. I think they’re called ‘S.I.S’.
DOCTOR: You’ve been in touch with the Secret Intelligence Service?
QUICKSILVER: by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 24
KINVAR: I thought that they could help. I had little to offer them... but I’d no need of it any more. They seemed excited at first. Talking about technological breakthroughs... But they didn’t really know much about you. Or your Ship. Then they became rather insistent.. I thought it best to get away.
DOCTOR: Kinvar, what have you done?
KINVAR: I traded... some of my technology for information. About you.
DOCTOR: What?! Your technology has no business on Earth. Especially not now. This war is coming to an end. The last thing the planet needs is for it to start up again, with an arms race no-one has any hope of winning. (ANGRY) Of all the irresponsible idiocy!
KINVAR: I’m sorry.
DOCTOR: And if you came here on the trail of Mrs Clarke, then your armoured friends could know about her too.
DOCTOR: ACTIVATES DOOR CONTROL.
KINVAR: What are you doing? We can’t go out there!
DOCTOR: Come, or stay behind. I don’t care. But I do want to make sure my friend is safe.
DOCTOR: EXITS.
DOCTOR: (CALLING, OUTSIDE) And if you do stay in there, don’t touch anything!
DOORS: CLOSE.
KINVAR: (TO SELF) I’m sorry. I’m sorry. I just don’t want to fight.
QUICKSILVER: by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 25
QUICKSILVER: SCENE 19: INT. VILAL SHIP
QUICKSILVER: HUMMING, CLUNKING & FAILING TECHNOLOGY.
VILAL GENERAL: Report Captain.
VILAL CAPTAIN: The enemy are running long range vortex scans. It is only a matter of time before they identify our spacetime location.
VILAL GENERAL: Did we find out anything about the blue box?
VILAL CAPTAIN: No General. But we did find this. The pilot - this ‘Doctor’ — may have dropped it outside. (HANDS INVITATION CARD TO VILAL
GENERAL: )
VILAL GENERAL: (TURNS OVER CARD) A primitive communication? Not the key, then.
VILAL CAPTAIN: No. But it may be a key. There is biodata on this paper. Some too complex for our analysis.
VILAL GENERAL: The Doctor’s?
VILAL CAPTAIN: We think so. There is also a human trace. They may also know about the box.
VILAL: GENERAL ACTIVATES CONTROLS.
VILAL GENERAL: Then locate it. Commence scans for this biodata and for Kinvar!
VILAL CAPTAIN: It appears that entering that vessel has removed him from local spacetime.
VILAL GENERAL: Divert all remaining power to the vortex scanner. Kinvar cannot stay inside that thing forever. He must emerge at some point. And we must find him!
QUICKSILVER: by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 26
QUICKSILVER: SCENE 20: INT. KITCHEN, CONSTANCE’S HOUSE
FRONT: DOOR OPENS AND CLOSES, OFF. DOCTOR HURRIES IN ALONG HALL.
KETTLE: STILL BOILING DRY, WHISTLING.
DOCTOR: (CALLING IN HALL) Only me! I’m sorry to barge back in, Mrs Clarke, but our goodbyes have been rudely interrupted. (ENTERING KITCHEN, TAKING KETTLE OFF HEAT) Goodness, this has almost boiled dry.
PLACES: KETTLE IN SINK. IT HISSES.
DOCTOR: (CARRIES ON REGARDLESS) Yes. I’m afraid we have an alien interloper on our hands. And he has some rather unsavoury heavies on his tail. It may be wise if we delay our parting until- (BREAKS OFF, REALISING CONSTANCE HASN’T SAID A WORD) Mrs Clarke? Is everything all right?
CONSTANCE: (DEEP BREATH) Not really, Dr Smith.
DOCTOR: Constance. Have you been crying?
CONSTANCE: No. (GATHERING HERSELF) Yes. Sorry. Alien interloper, you say. Of course.
DOCTOR: He can wait. What is it, Mrs Clarke? Has something happened?
CONSTANCE: You might say that. That undelivered telegram was delivered.
CONSTANCE: PUSHES TELEGRAM ACROSS TABLE. THE DOCTOR PICKS IT UP.
DOCTOR: From the War Office. (READING) ‘Deeply regret to inform you’- (BREAKS OFF) Oh no.
CONSTANCE: Lieutenant Commander Henry Clarke. Lost in action. Two weeks ago. Classified operations. They can’t even tell me where it was that he- (STOPS HERSELF)
DOCTOR: Constance.
QUICKSILVER: by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 27
CONSTANCE: I think I knew. I think I knew that I’d lost him long before he
CONSTANCE: went away.
QUICKSILVER: by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 28
QUICKSILVER: SCENE 21: INT. BEDROOM, CONSTANCE’S HOUSE [FLASHBACK]
QUICKSILVER: FOLLOWING ON FROM FLASHBACK SCENE 11. FRONT DOOR CLOSES. CAR
HONKS: OUTSIDE.
CONSTANCE: OPENS WINDOW.
HENRY: (OUTSIDE, CALLING) Goodbye, darling!
CONSTANCE: (CALLING) Goodbye!
CAR: DRIVES AWAY. CONSTANCE WAITS A MOMENT, THEN CLOSES WINDOW.
RUSHES: ACROSS ROOM, OPENS WARDROBE, PULLS OUT CLOTHES, SEARCHING.
CONSTANCE: (TO SELF) How long, Henry? How long has this been going on?
CONSTANCE: STARTS PULLING OUT DRAWERS. A STASH OF LETTERS FALLS
FROM: UNDERNEATH ONE OF THE DRAWERS.
CONSTANCE: (GASPS) No. No.
CONSTANCE: PICKS UP LETTERS.
CONSTANCE: (READING LETTER) ‘My darling H. How many weeks until we meet again?’ (THROWS DOWN LETTER) No! Who is she? How could you, Henry? How could you?
PICKS: UP ANOTHER.
CONSTANCE: (STEELS HERSELF WITH A BREATH, AND READS) ‘Every time we part,
CONSTANCE: I die a little. I await you now, on the platform. Every time we have met through this terrible conflict, you have brought hope
CONSTANCE: into my life...
ANA: (OVERLAPPING CONSTANCE) -you have brought hope into my life. Some small hope that one day, this war will end. And that we can be together.
QUICKSILVER: by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 29
QUICKSILVER: SCENE 22: EXT. TRAIN PLATFORM, VIENNA [FLASHBACK]
TRAIN: PULLS INTO PLATFORM. CROWDS BUSTLING. HENRY HURRIES ALONG PLATFORM.
HENRY: (ARRIVING) Ana! Ana.
ANA: Henry. I have you for how long this time?
ANA: THEY WALKING ALONG PLATFORM TOGETHER, SPEAKING CLOSELY.
HENRY: A few months. Until we’ve secured certain routes and certain people from the east.
ANA: The Russian bear keeps roaring. The Axis is stalled. But it means more people than ever are fleeing through the hills and the forests. From Hungary, Poland, Romania. From my own Bucharest.
HENRY: I know. We can assist. There are some names I’ve been asked to look out for. Scientists, officials.
ANA: And who is helping me this time?
HENRY: Mr Harry Cook. Trader in fine linens. I have all the relevant papers. While I’m here, I’m officially a civilian. So I suppose technically, that makes you my commanding officer. I must obey your every order.
ANA: (STOPPING) In that case, Mr Cook, I order you to kiss me.
HENRY: And I am happy to comply.
HENRY: THEY EMBRACE AND KISS. PEOPLE PASS ON THE PLATFORM.
TRAIN: WHISTLE BLOWS SEVERAL TIMES. IT STARTS TO MOVE OFF, STEAM
BLOWS: AROUND THEM.
QUICKSILVER: by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 30
QUICKSILVER: SCENE 23: INT. KITCHEN, CONSTANCE’S HOUSE
TRANSITION: BACK TO PRESENT. A MOMENT OF SILENCE.
DOCTOR: I am so very, very sorry for your loss.
CONSTANCE: (BUSINESSLIKE) Tell me Doctor. What of this alien? You say he needs our help?
DOCTOR: Yes. He does but-
CONSTANCE: (OVER HIM) Then how can I refuse a call to arms? One more tour of duty, Doctor. Helping the helpless. Defending the defenceless. Freeing the oppressed.
CONSTANCE: PUSHES HER CHAIR AND STANDS.
CONSTANCE: Home can wait until another time.
DOCTOR: But Constance-
CONSTANCE: Please Doctor. I’d like to do this. I need to do this.
CONSTANCE: WALKS TO HALL.
DOCTOR: I suppose it may help... (FOLLOWING, TO SELF) And I know from experience, if you’ve already set your mind to it, I certainly
DOCTOR: can’t stop you.
DOCTOR: SCENE 24: EXT. CONSTANCE’S STREET
TARDIS: DOORS CLOSE AND DEMATERIALISATION STARTS, CONTINUING INTO:
QUICKSILVER: by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 31
QUICKSILVER: SCENE 25: INT. VILAL SHIP
VILAL: SCANNERS RUNNING, PICKING UP FAINT SOUND OF TARDIS DEMATERIALISATION. HUMMING, CLUNKING & FAILING TECHNOLOGY AS BEFORE.
VILAL CAPTAIN: The unknown vessel has departed, General.
VILAL GENERAL: Scan for his psycho-trace! We cannot lose Kinvar.
VILAL CAPTAIN: I am trying. Our systems are failing.
MORE: FAILING MACHINES POWER DOWN.
VILAL GENERAL: (GRUMBLING) We are almost out of power. We cannot keep moving from place to place with no results!
VILAL GENERAL: AN ALERT SOUNDS.
VILAL CAPTAIN: A contact! Kinvar! He is still on this world. Four years from now. But that Ship is there too.
VILAL GENERAL: So Kinvar is still with this ‘Doctor’. He will try to defend him again. We need a tactic to persuade him. What of the thing found outside the box? The communication? Does it provide another way? Something we can use?
CLUNKING: VORTEX SCOOP MANOUEVRES INTO PLACE.
VILAL CAPTAIN: There was a time and location enscribed on it. Tracing...
BEEPING: ALERT.
VILAL CAPTAIN: Objective found. A human biodata match. (CHECKING READOUTS) More than sixty solar orbits from now.. I do not think we can spare the power.
VILAL GENERAL: It is not your job to think, Captain! This is our only clue. Activate the vortex scoop.
VILAL CAPTAIN: General, we will not have sufficient energy to-
QUICKSILVER: by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 32
VILAL GENERAL: Bring our vessel into local spacetime at Kinvar’s next contact point. We will use this ‘thing’ to force the Doctor to co- operate.
VILAL CAPTAIN: If we do this General, then once we land, we will not be able to relocate the ship-
VILAL GENERAL: (SHOUTING OVER HIM) Then that is where we make our final stand! The last hope of the Vilal rests with us. We have no choice. Activate the scoop!
QUICKSILVER: by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 33
QUICKSILVER: SCENE 26: EXT. OUTSIDE RECEPTION HALL, 2012
QUICKSILVER: 21°* CENTURY PARTY MUSIC IN HALL IN BACKGROUND.
QUICKSILVER: PARTY GUESTS: (INSIDE HALL, LAUGHING, PARTYING).
DOORS: OPEN, NOISE INSIDE HEARD LOUDER. FLIP STEPS OUT AND WALKS
PAST: PARTY GUESTS.
FLIP: Phew. That’s one thing they don’t ever tell you about getting married. How completely knackering it is!
GUESTS: (CHEERS AS FLIP PASSES) ‘Congratulations!’ ‘Well done!’ ‘Party on!’
FLIP: (WALKS OUT) Thanks! See you in there! (CALLING BACK) Tell Jared I’ll be back for another go at Gangnam Style in a minute. I’m having a breather.
GUESTS: GO BACK INTO HALL. MASSIVE FEEDBACK ON SPEAKERS IN HALL AND MUSIC STOPS, CROWD INSIDE REACTS, GROANING, BOOING.
FLIP: (TUTS) Dodgy Steve. Dodgy speakers. I told Jared he shouldn’t have- (STOPS HERSELF)
FLIP: TAKES A FEW STEPS AWAY FROM PARTY.
FLIP: (SIGHS, TO SELF) Ah well. Too late now, Philippa. You’ve really gone and done it. For better or [worse. ]
FLIP: FIZZING, CRACKLING IN THE AIR.
FLIP: Hold up. What’s that? (CALLING) Hello?
FLIP: TAKES A FEW STEPS TOWARDS WHIRLING VORTEX.
QUICKSILVER: by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 34
FLIP: Uh-oh. (HAPPY REALISATION) Of course! Weird floaty whirlpool, hanging in the air? It’s got to be you, Doctor. (CALLING TO
VORTEX: — SHE THINKS THE TARDIS IS ARRIVING) I knew you wouldn’t miss it! Doctor? I was really hoping you’d make it along! OK, so you have missed the registry office. And the first punch-up. But there should still be some cake left. I saved some especially.
FIZZING: VORTEX CRACKLES AND SWIRLS OMINOUSLY.
FLIP: (WALKS ON TOWARDS IT) Doctor? Are you there? Is that — [you]
FLIP: WITH A DISTORTED VILAL ROAR, THE VORTEX SCOOP SUDDENLY REACHES OUT, ENGULFS FLIP AND SWEEPS HER AWAY.
FLIP: END OF PART ONE
QUICKSILVER: by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 35

elements.text: PART TWO
SCENE 27: EXT. BOMBED OUT STREET, VIENNA
ZITHER MUSIC.
TRAFFIC PASSES, CAR HORNS. A CROOK WALKS HIS DOG INTO STREET, WHISTLING. DOG PANTS AND BARKS.
(URGENT WHISPER) Schmidt? Where are you?
IS DISTURBED, OFF.
(CALLING) Is that you, Schmidt? Nice place to do business. I have the.. medicines you ordered.
BARKS.
And also protection, in case you decide to change the terms of our deal!
FALLS, OFF.
Well? What are you waiting for?
BARKS AND RUNS INTO RUBBLE.
(RUNNING AFTER) Hey! Baron! Come back!
CLIMBS TO WHERE DOG IS SNUFFLING AT A BODY.
What’s that you’ve found, boy? Oh. A body.
STEPS CLOSER AND TURNS OVER BODY.
Horrible. Burned. (GASPS, RECOGNISING IT) Schmidt!
GENERAL STOMPS OVER RUBBLE TOWARDS CROOK. DOG BARKS AND GROWLS.
Who... Who are you? (BEAT, REALISING IT’S INHUMAN) What are you? You did this? You killed Schmidt! (FUMBLES TO DRAW GUN) Stop right there, or I shoot!
STOMPS ONWARD.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 36
I warned you!
FIRES GUN. BULLET RICOCHETS OFF ARMOUR. VILAL VISOR RAISES.
That is an act of aggression. I must retaliate.
RAISES WEAPON AND FIRES.
No! No- Aaaargh! (DEATH CRY)
WHIMPERS AND RUNS AWAY.
The animal will not talk.
STOMPS AWAY.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 37
SCENE 28: EXT. VIENNA STREET
ZITHER MUSIC. VIENNA STREET. TRAFFIC. OCCASIONAL HORN. PEOPLE PASSING. FLIP WALKS ALONG WITH ANA THROUGH FOLLOWING.
It’s really nice of you. To look after me. I’m sorry, I’ve no clue at all how I got here. I can’t quite remember.
Wurden sie Verloren? (Pron: ‘Ver-dun zee fur-law-ren’) [German: Were you lost?]
Sorry. I don’t spreckendie. (‘sprek-en-dee’ )
No. I forget. I am so used to everyone speaking German here.
And here is...
Kaerntnerstrasse. (‘carnt-ner-strass’ )
Come again?
The best shopping street in Vienna.
(TO SELF) Yeah, Vienna. That’s what I thought you said. (TO ANA) I like the ferris wheel. Just the place for a holiday. (SOTTO) It must be him. It’s gotta be him!
Had you been at some kind of party, Miss Philips?
You could say that. And it’s Flip. Philippa Jackson. Well, Mrs Philippa Ramon now, I suppose.
I see, Mrs Ramon. Your fancy dress is most unusual. I have not seen this style before.
Yeah, it’s not fancy dress exactly. More a sort of... Never mind.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 38
Whatever you say, Mrs Ramon.
Actually, let’s stick with ‘Flip’.
I am sorry we have only gentlemen’s clothes in our shop. And my own would be too tall for you, I think.
THEY STOP OUTSIDE SHOP.
Take a look in the windows. See if there is anything you like.
That’s ever so kind of you.
I have always done my best to help those in need. (BEAT) Are you running from something, Miss Flip?
No. Not exactly. (BEAT) I’m thinking, this must be to do with the Doctor. You’re sure you don’t know him?
You need a doctor? Do you feel unwell?
No. I don’t think so.
Perhaps you are still confused from your journey?
I reckon I must be.
OPENS SHOP DOOR, BELL RINGS INSIDE.
This is a good place, yes? (ENTERS SHOP)

Yeah. Right behind you. (BEAT, THEN SOTTO) It’s him, isn’t it? Just the kind of thing he’d do. Spring a surprise honeymoon. Only someone should have told him. If you’re going on honeymoon, it’s normal to bring your husband along!
ENTERS SHOP.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 39
SCENE 29: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
TARDIS IN FLIGHT. SCANNING AND BEEPS.
Ah, a hit. (CHECKING ALERT) A palpable hit!
This dangerous alien technology?

(WORKING AT CONSOLE) The TARDIS didn’t have much to go on. We don’t have a sample, you see. I’m just having her search for any anachronistic signals, while running a cross-check on all the names and dates Kinvar has been able to provide.
Is there anything I can do? There may be people I know from the military.
(COVERING WHAT HE’S REALLY DOING) Oh, don’t worry yourself. The
has it all in hand.
(THINKING HE’S MOLLYCODDLING HER) I can cope, you know. A Wren is always able to focus on the job in hand. Whatever personal concerns she might have.
I don’t doubt it. But your recent news constitutes something rather more than a ‘personal concern’. (BEAT) Constance, there
are stages of grief-
I’d rather not speak about the matter any further. I will deal with things in my own way.
Very well. But I am here, if you need... anything.
I am aware of that. (BEAT) Thank you.
Why don’t you see if our guest has woken from his nap? Show him the food machine. Oh! He may need some outerwear that’s a little less conspicuous. And a hat, perhaps.
Certainly. Back in two ticks.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 40
EXITS TO CORRIDOR.
(GOING OFF, CALLING) Mr Kinvar! Rise and shine. There’s work to be done.
BEEPS. DOCTOR GOES TO CHECK READOUT.
Well, well, well. Now that’s very odd. Very odd indeed. (BEAT) Shouldn’t you be dead?
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 41
SCENE 30: INT. HENRY’S SHOP
RUSTLES.
HUMS TO SELF, TURNS PAGE) Treaty of Brussels, eh? (TO SELF
Uniting against the Communist threat. Jolly good show.
DOOR OPENS, BELL RINGS, AS ANA ENTERS.
We are home!
(OUTSIDE) Thanks Ana. I really feel the part in this getup.
FOLLOWS HER IN.
You seem so much better. Ah. Here is my husband. Hard at work!
PUTS DOWN NEWSPAPER, STANDS.
Good work, ladies. That’s much better than that strange outfit you were wearing when we found you.
Yeah... I was just saying to your missus. I’m very grateful to you both for taking me in.
A confused young woman, wandering about the bombsites. As a fellow Brit I felt I should take responsibility! I don’t know if you remember anything from when I found you...?
Not much. Mr... Cook, was it?
Harry. And this is our shop. Our humble little clothing outlet. Vienna has been good to us. Which reminds me, I have a meeting with our... ‘supplier’ this afternoon.
Of course. You should go soon.
I hope I’m not in the way.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 42
No, no. Not at all. Just some restocking. Trade’s been very brisk of late.
But not so brisk that you cannot spend all morning reading a newspaper?
A fellow should keep up with international events. Especially now! We live in exciting times.
Yeah. So, the Second World War’s over, right?
(LAUGHS) It has been for a few years now. You’re certain she’s recovering, Ana? Miss Flip, are you sure you didn’t hit your head when you arrived? You were in rather a state.
No. I’m pretty sure I’m not injured at all. Just... you know... weirded out.
I’m not sure if I do know.
There is one thing. Do you mind me asking, what year is it exactly?
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 43
SCENE 31: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
B/G HUM. TARDIS BEEPS AN ALERT.
Nineteen-forty-eight! That’s when your technology next shows up, Kinvar. Active and dangerous.
You’ve set our destination?
SETS TARDIS IN FLIGHT.
I’m doing it now... Ah, Vienna! We’re on our way.
I am so sorry. I meant no harm. I only wanted to get away.
Whatever your intent, that technology needs switching off and removing. I’m afraid I’1ll need you to accompany me to find it.
Isn’t there a danger that those creatures will be waiting? Those...?
Vilal. Yes. I’m rather hoping they are.
You want them to take me?
No. But if we meet them, then perhaps I can find out what exactly it is they want with you. You are remaining rather tight-lipped on the subject.
STRIDES ROUND CONSOLE. CHECKING FLIGHT.
See what I mean? Now, we shall be arriving shortly. Ah. Constance. You might like to change. Those colours may draw unwanted attention.
You’re one to talk of colours!
I shall be wearing my Bletchley tweed.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 44
Doctor, you know I’m proud of the Wren uniform-
(STOPS HER) Of course I do. It may be a little distracting, in peacetime.
Nineteen-forty-eight. Of course... The war is over?

Where we’re going, Europe is just starting to work out how to rebuild after the chaos. Vienna is run by the Allied Control Council. Britain, Russia, France and America have divided the city into zones. There’s a shared international zone in the centre, which they patrol together. The ‘four in a jeep’ method.
I understand. One soldier from each country.
It’s the best way to keep the peace. But even now, their tempers are starting to fray with one another. (ASIDE) Humans, they can’t help looking for new enemies...
Then perhaps on this occasion, discretion would be advisable. (EXITING) I shall find some suitable civilian wear.
Thank you. (BEAT, CLOSE) Kinvar, while Mrs Clarke changes, I have something I want to show you...
TAPS CONSOLE.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 45
SCENE 32: INT. CALLAHAN’S OFFICE
OUTSIDE. BOYAROV KNOCKS.
(CALLING) Come! (AS BOYAROV ENTERS) Ah, Major Boyarov. This must be important for you to come to my office in person.
(ENTERING) Major Callahan. I have news. Not good, I’m afraid.
Don’t tell me. More bodies?
I am afraid it is true. Two more bodies. A dog led us to them.
(SIGH) Where this time?
You might guess. In the bombed-out backstreets near Hoher Markt.
The usual places haunted by black marketeers and pickpockets. Have you identified the victims?
The corpses were charred, but we believe they are two of our less savoury citizens. Known thieves and criminals. What does it matter if they kill one another?
What matters is that we’re supposed to be keeping the peace.
PLACES FILES ON DESK.
Here. Our report. I have filed this also with the Americans and the French.
TAKES FILES AND FLICKS THROUGH PAPERS.
It’s the state of these bodies that concerns me most. What on
Earth could do that?
Something powerful.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 46
That’s what worries me. If there is a new weapon on the streets
of Vienna, then we are all at risk.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 47
SCENE 33: INT. VILAL SHIP
CLUNKING AND HUMMING VILAL TECHNOLOGY. SOMETHING IS WRONG WITH
SYSTEMS ARE DYING.
Soon. It must be soon. Our ship is failing. We cannot wait much longer.
The humans get closer. Soon their military forces will discover us. And we cannot move. We.. cannot kill them all.
GENERAL SLAMS FIST ON CONTROLS.
(ANGRY GRUNT) This is not acceptable! This is not how Vilal die! Hiding, in the craters of some other war!
FIZZING OF ZERITH COMMUNICATION.
Another communication, General.
And still our enemy taunts us.
(FX, DISTORTED TUNING IN) Vilal! Hear us! Wherever you are hiding! The Zerith have your home-world under siege. We are coming for you.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 48
SCENE 34: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
B/G HUM. DOCTOR ACTIVATES SCANNER.
(CLOSE) Tell me, Kinvar. Do you recognise this man?
Yes. That’s Mr Clarke!
Shh! And you last saw him, when exactly? It’s important you remember precisely how long before you hammered on my door.
I met with him only a few times. The first was some time after I missed you both at Bletchley. But the last meeting, his people arranged — three days before you and Mrs Clarke arrived.
The War Office telegram predates that meeting. That’s what’s strange. Dead men don’t tend to keep their appointments.
This picture. It shows a different name.
But it’s still the face of the man in the wedding photo in Constance’s hallway. I set the TARDIS searching through military records. S.I.S., as you said.
He was very interested in the technology. Mr Clarke promised to help, but I had to keep moving. In case they came.

It’s not unknown for covert operatives to fake their own deaths in order to go undercover. But I can’t raise Constance’s hopes unless I’m sure. Let’s see what he was working on. (USES CONTROLS) The TARDIS has accessed the secret service files, declassified in the twenty-first century. I’m not breaking the rules of time travel exactly, just bending them a little...
SCREENS FLICKS THROUGH IMAGES.
Look! That is my device. The thing I gave him. (SOTTO) The Helm of Vilal.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 49
As I thought. The same technology. The same man. Henry Clarke is here in Vienna. Working on an operation... Codenamed Quicksilver.
I do not understand.
Constance thinks her husband is dead. But all the evidence says he’s right here. Right now.
PRINTS FROM CONSOLE.

Living as a Mr Harry Cook. I’ve printed off an address from Military Police records. (RIPS OFF PAPER AND PASSES IT TO KINVAR) File it with the other information. You and I will look into it properly later. I’1ll give Mrs Clarke some errands in the meantime.
Yes Doctor, (PUTTING PAPERS IN FILES) Thank you, Doctor.
APPROACHES ALONG TARDIS CORRIDOR.
(OFF, CALLING) You really should organise that wardrobe. Formal wear alongside animal skins... Silver sequins, I ask you! It’s hard to find something practical.
HURRIEDLY SWITCHES OFF MONITOR.
(CLOSE, TO KINVAR) One more thing. Not a word to Constance,
until I find out more.
No, no. Of course. Whatever you say.
(ENTERING) Here we are. What do you think?
I think that’s excellent timing, Mrs Clarke! We’re landing!
STARTS MATERIALISATION.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 50
SCENE 35: INT. HOTEL BAR
MUSIC IN BACKGROUND.
Whisky and water for me, thank you.
APPROACHES FROM BEHIND. DRINK IS PLACED ON COUNTER.
Let me get that, Major.
PUTS COINS ON BAR.
Thank you, Mr Cook. How’s the rag trade?
I can’t complain.
Good to see British business flourishing in Vienna. I do like to keep an eye on my fellow countrymen. (BEAT, SIPS DRINK, CLOSE) And Quicksilver?
(CLOSE) Is up and running. It took a while, but those new machines can certainly do the job. The ‘other party’ providing assistance has gone quiet. I’m not sure if they’ve left.
I don’t want to know, Mr Cook. (WALKS ACROSS BAR) Let’s take a private booth shall we? And you can tell me what you’ve heard...
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 51
SCENE 36: EXT. OUTSIDE TARDIS, VIENNA STREET
OPENS. DOCTOR AND CONSTANCE STEP OUTSIDE ONTO COBBLES
Here we are. Off the beaten track. Behind the Hofburg.
Goodness. Even in the half-light, it’s all rather beautiful.
The parts of Vienna still standing are. Unfortunately many streets were reduced to rubble.
By Allied bombs...
One can understand why the locals might be a little suspicious of foreign powers. Of any flag.
So Doctor. Where do we start?
I thought you might investigate the local news agencies. Look for any unusual incidents. Kinvar and I have some other leads to check. Addresses... (CALLING) Kinvar! Come along! Bring that list!
Jolly good. Should we meet back here at-
CRIES IN PAIN
STUMBLES OUT OF TARDIS, FALLING ONTO COBBLES, DROPPING
FILE.
(GOING TO HELP) Oh my word. Mr Kinvar!
(MOANS) Vilal! They are here! Agh! My mind is under attack...
Some form of psychic reaction. It may even be his own technology causing it. If British Intelligence have Quicksilver up and running-
MOANS IN PAIN
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 52
Tend to the poor boy. You’re a Doctor, after all. I imagine you’ve much more experience of alien biology than I.
I may be able to block it, or at least reduce the effect until we can turn it off. (EFFORT) First, I’1ll get him back inside the TARDIS.
DRAGS KINVAR TOWARDS TARDIS DOORS.
If this is down to those creatures, then we clearly have no time to lose in finding them.
(DRAGGING KINVAR) I should have expected this. All we need is a shielding psionic crystal boosted with an energy lattice. I’ve quite a selection to choose from.
PICKS UP KINVAR’S FILE.
Is this all the information you have? Then I’1l make a start myself. (STRIDES OFF) Shall we say, back here in one hour?
QUICKLY HURRIES OFF OVER COBBLES AND ROUND CORNER.
Yes, yes. The sooner we find Quicksilver and shut it down the better. Let’s get you back inside, young man. (REALISES WHAT SHE’S GOT, CALLING) Constance, no, not those files! Wait!
(MOANS) Help me...
Ah. Too late.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 53
SCENE 37: EXT. VIENNA STREET
ZITHER MUSIC. FLIP WALKS ALONG. HENRY STEPS OUT OF BAR.
Mr Cook! There you are. Your wife said you might be at the hotel bar.
Miss Flip! What are you doing here? Ana really shouldn’t have let you come alone. Come along. We should get you back.
LEANDS FLIP ALONG STREET.
But I’m starting to feel like my old self. I can’t sit around and do nothing. I need to find out why I’m here.
You mean you remember where you came from?
I do. A bit.
And?
It’s not that I’m hiding anything. It’s more that you’d never believe me if I told you.
Let’s get you home. I promise. If nothing’s changed by morning, I’ll take you to someone in authority. I do have connections.
THEY WALK ON.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 54
SCENE 38: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
HELP KINVAR BACK INSIDE.
(EFFORT, SUPPORTING KINVAR) Here. Inside the TARDIS, you should feel better. I’1l have to put something together to shield you.
(RECOVERING) Thank you, Doctor. What about Constance? She went looking for Quicksilver?
She did. And she has Harry Cook’s address as a starting point. (SIGH) I only hope it turns out for the best.
Her husband’s alive when she thought he was dead. Surely that will be good news?
You're right. It may be a shock, but I think any reunion can only make her happy.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 55
SCENE 39: EXT. VIENNA STREET
EXPLORES VIENNA STREETS TO A ZITHER SOUNDTRACK.
(TO SELF) Pressegasse. Which way now? Ah.
FOOTSTEPS IN DISTANCE.
(OFF) Thanks Mr Cook. You’ve been too good to me.
(OFF) My pleasure, Philippa.
(SHAKEN, SOTTO) Oh my. It can’t be...
RUNS TO HIDE IN DOORWAY. CAT MIAOWS.
Shush. Out of the way, kitty. I need your hideyhole.
STEPS INSIDE DOORWAY. FLIP AND HENRY WALK ON PAST.
(AS THEY PASS) Here we are. Home again. I must say, we’ve done
rather well with that outfit. You look very elegant.
Why thank you, Mr C.
UNLOCKS SHOP DOOR, JUST OFF.
After you, Philippa.
(LAUGHS) Such a gentleman!
THEY ENTER SHOP. CONSTANCE STEPS FROM HER HIDING PLACE.
(STUNNED) Henry... Oh, Henry.
MIAOWS.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 56
SCENE 40: EXT. SEWER ENTRANCE, VIENNA
DOCTOR AND KINVAR WALK ALONG COBBLES TOWARDS SEWER ENTRANCE.
Well then. According to the TARDIS scans, we need to go
underground, Kinvar.
Underground?
Into the sewers, I’m afraid. (EFFORT)
OPENS SECTIONAL MANHOLE COVERS.
Still no ill effects?
No Doctor. This pendant is working.
(CLIMBING INTO MANHOLE) A simple psionic shield. And the crystal should start to glow as we close in on the technology.
CLIMBS DOWN INTO TUNNEL.
(CLIMBING, BELOW) And I’m afraid the pain may return.
FOLLOWS.
(CLIMBING) I understand. It is my fault. The sooner we take this ‘Quicksilver’, the sooner we can go.
THEY SPLASH INTO WATER BELOW AND START WALKING.
MUSIC TRANSITION.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 57
SCENE 41: INT. SEWER TUNNELS
ATMOS. RUNNING WATER IN DISTANCE. DOCTOR AND KINVAR WALK
SEWER TUNNEL.
This way, I think. (EFFORT) A door off the main sewer.
PUSHES DOOR OPEN.
What have we here?
Cables. Wires. Perhaps it is this city’s communication network?
I’d say it’s more than a ‘perhaps’. (EDGING INSIDE) It’s a bit of a squeeze. But there’s a way through.
EDGES INTO NARROW PASSAGE.
(WINCES) Agh! I feel it!
Proof positive. We’re close.
THEY ENTER PASSAGE. DOOR CLANGS SHUT BEHIND THEM.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 58
SCENE 42: INT. HENRY’S SHOP
WALKS THROUGH SHOP IN NEW COAT.
Very dapper, Mrs Ramon. Whoever picked that coat out had an eye for your hair.
(LAUGHS) Colour came out of a bottle, [Mr C.]
OPENS, SHOP BELL RINGS. CONSTANCE ENTERS.
Well isn’t this nice. What a charming scene.
(GOBSMACKED BEAT) Constance? Constance, is that you?
It is, Henry. I must say. Death does seem to agree with you. Such a glow in your cheeks. Not convinced by the moustache, though.
How did you find me?
Aren’t you gonna introduce us?
And look. You’ve attracted a young admirer. Quite the ingénue.
Hiya, ‘Constance’, was it? You might have got the wrong idea. I’m Flip.
PUSHES FLIP AWAY.
I know what you are! And I have no wish to make your
acquaintance!
Hang on. Am I missing something here?
You are missing your morals. He is a married man.
I know! I’m a married woman!
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 59
Yet you flaunt your grubby liaison as if it’s something to be proud of!
Whoah there. Maybe you should go out and come in again? Cos I’m not getting any of this. And I don’t like how you’re talking to me.
Constance. Please. Let me explain. Philippa has just arrived. We hardly know each other.
Even worse! Then I shall enlighten her. This, young woman, is my husband. Lieutenant Commander Henry Clarke of His Majesty’s navy.
The war is over, Constance.
Yet you didn’t come home.
I tried. You weren’t there.
Listen. You two have things to talk about. Maybe I should-
OPENS, SHOP BELL RINGS. ANA ENTERS.
Henry? Who is this?
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 60
SCENE 43: INT. CABLE TUNNEL
TUNNEL ATMOS. LOW HUM OF QUICKSILVER DEVICES.
This is it. Operation Quicksilver. Those silver boxes, laid along the cables.
This is not my device. There are more. This was not my doing.
Never underestimate human ingenuity. The important thing is (EFFORT — REMOVING DEVICE) now we’ve found them, to get them far away from this time and place.
Why are they here?
Of course. These are telecommunication cables. The British are using them to tap the Russian lines. No sooner does one war end, than another one starts. A very cold one. (EFFORT,

DEVICES) If only they knew the true potential of these devices. Their psychic potential. They can change how people think. Instead of simply listening in on conversations with the Kremlin, they could actually influence them.
FINISHES REMOVING DEVICES AND STEPS CLEAR. HE FIDDLES WITH THEM, THEY PULSE AND HUM UNDER FOLLOWING.

There. That’s all of them. Whatever possessed you to give humans access to this kind of technology? It’s the last thing the Earth should get hold of at this point in its history. Communism, McCarthyism. They’ll manage all that brainwashing and paranoia quite well enough on their own, thank you very much.
I didn’t! I gave Henry Clarke one component. (CRIES IN PAIN)
(STOPS FIDDLING) Are you all right, Kinvar?
(RECOVERING) Yes. I think so.
Sorry. Just seeing how the controls work. (SETS OFF) Let’s find the quickest way out of here, shall we?
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 61
SCENE 44: INT. HENRY’S SHOP
This is Constance? I thought you had told her.
I tried. She wasn’t there.
(TO ANA) You. It was you who wrote the letters. You who waited on the platform.
I am sorry you should find out this way. We did not mean to hurt you. Henry was not happy. But we have made a new life.
Well isn’t that nice for you?
Don’t blame Ana. It was me. All me.
And what else have you done, Henry? First bigamy. Now you’ve moved on to shop girls!
Oi! I’m not a shop girl. I work in a supermarket. (REALISES
SHE’S SAID) OK. Technically I am a shop girl. But that’s no reason to start assuming stuff about me! Me and him? No way!
Please Constance. We can talk about this calmly. (PULLS UP A CHAIR) Here. Sit down.
Do not come near me, Henry. Or I will not be responsible for my actions!
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 62
SCENE 45: EXT. SEWER EXIT, VIENNA STREET
DOCTOR AND KINVAR CLIMB STEPS AND EXIT SEWER.
(BREATHING DEEP) Here we are. Fresh air at last.
Where are we now?
No point retracing our steps underground. I found the quickest route to the surface. Which means, if my calculations are correct, we’re on the edge of-
The Russian zone.
BOYAROV AND SOLDIERS STEP FORWARD.
Your hands in the air, I think.
Please. I’m in the process of removing highly dangerous technology. I need to make it safe.
No. Put those boxes down.
Best do as he says, Kinvar. Please. Major...?
Major Boyarov. On the floor if you please.
DOCTOR AND KINVAR PLACE DEVICES ON COBBLED GROUND.
(SIGH) Why is the military mind never open to persuasion?
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 63
SCENE 46: EXT. OUTSIDE HENRY’S SHOP
DRIVES ALONG. CRASHING OF THROWN GLASSES INSIDE SHOP.
You hear that? Sounds like a fight.
COMMOTION IN SHOP, CROCKERY SMASHES, THROWN CHAIR. JEEP
UP.
Ivanov. Arnaud — stay with the Jeep. Jenkins, with me.
GRUNTS
(OFF INSIDE SHOP, CALLING) Please, Constance! Calm down!
APPROACH AND KNOCK.
(CALLING) Open up!
(OFF INSIDE SHOP, ANGRY) Calm! My husband reveals himself as serial adulterer! You expect me to be calm?!
OPENS DOOR.
Hiya. You the police? I expect you want to know what all the
fuss is about. You’d better come in.
ENTER.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 64
SCENE 47: INT. HENRY’S SHOP (CONTINUOUS)
ENTER. CONSTANCE HAS STOPPED SMASHING THINGS.
There. I am calm. I am perfectly calm.
Do you people need help?
I’m sorry, officers. There really is no need to trouble yourselves.
We can sit down and discuss the situation as adults. All of us.
Hang on. Don’t get me involved. I’m only here till the Doctor shows up.
I beg your pardon?
(OUTSIDE, CALLING) Someone is coming! Outside! Soldiers.
That’s awful strange. First time I ever heard Boris speak a word of English.
(GOING TO WINDOW) There is something out there.
Away from the window, Ana!
A dozen men in armour. No. I think they are not men. Oh my. I see their faces, I do not think they are of this world at all.
Monsters... Russians speaking English... (REALISES) Ahh. I know what’s happening.
STOMP TOWARDS SHOP.
It’s the TARDIS. He’s here!
What did you say, young lady?
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 65
PAUSE.
VILAL WEAPONFIRE AND EXPLOSION OUTSIDE.
OUTSIDE, CRY OUT
Oh no. Ana. Get upstairs.
No. I stay right by your side.
RUSH TO DOORWAY. RAISING GUNS.
Jenkins, with me. (CALLING) Who’s there! Halt or we fire!
STOMP TO DOORWAY AND OPEN FIRE.
DEATH CRIES
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 66
SCENE 48: EXT. BOMBED OUT VIENNA BACKSTREET
AS DOCTOR AND KINVAR ARE MARCHED INTO QUIET DEAD END ALLEY.
I demand to speak to someone in authority.
You already are. I am the authority here.
Please. Listen to the Doctor.
I listen to no-one where security is concerned. Beneath that street are communication lines to the Kremlin.
I know.
An admission of guilt! A quick and anonymous death is all your kind deserve.
Our kind?
Spies.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 67
SCENE 49: INT. HENRY’S SHOP
STOMP INSIDE.
No more weapons.
No! We have none!
We’re unarmed!
It is time. We have come for her.
Who’s he talking about?
All right. But there was really no need to kill those men.
Do not tell us what we can do.
Henry? You know these aliens?
Aliens. Of course. (ASIDE, MEANING THE DOCTOR & HER WEDDING INVITE) He couldn’t just bring a ‘plus one’.
Take her. But leave the others.
Wait a sec-
Henry? You can’t mean. (STEPPING FORWARD) No. You cannot take this young girl. (CRIES OUT, GRABBED)
PULLS CONSTANCE ASIDE AS VILAL ADVANCE ON FLIP.
Constance. Leave them be. They brought her here.
Let go! You may be my husband, but you’ve no right to take hold of me like a common criminal!
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 68
Henry said they need her alive. We have taken good care of her. I expect them to do the same.
SEIZE FLIP.
We are talking about the same blobs in armour who just blasted four people? (CRIES OUT) Agh! Get your hands off! (STRUGGLES)
It is time for you to fulfil your purpose. Take that one too.
SEIZE CONSTANCE.
Unhand me, you brutes! (STRUGGLES)
Henry?
No. Not Constance. That was not the agreement!
Agreement?
You’re handing me over to these metal-plated mud-men?
You are both friends of the Doctor. So the Vilal will take you both.
(SINKING IN) This girl’s a friend of the Doctor’s...?
Well, duh.
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 69
SCENE 50: EXT. BOMBED OUT VIENNA BACKSTREET
SCENE 48, DOCTOR AND KINVAR MARCHED ALONG BACKSTREET BY BOYAROV AND SOLDIERS.
Stop. Here will do.
HALT.
We are not the spies here. We have just removed the spying equipment.
So. You admit that is what these devices are for! Men. Present arms.
DRAW WEAPONS.
There really is no need for this...
One of you will die and one of you will talk. That is how it usually works with spies.
But we’ve already told you the truth!
Let us see if the story remains the same after the first bullets are fired. Ready weapons.
RAISE WEAPONS.
Doctor? They’re going to shoot us!
It does rather look that way.
Take aim.
STEP FORWARD, RACKING WEAPONS.
END OF PART TWO
by Matt Fitton (003—AB edits) Page 70

ANA: Whatever you say, Mrs Ramon.

NEWSPAPER: RUSTLES.

SHOP: DOOR OPENS, BELL RINGS, AS ANA ENTERS.
ANA: We are home!
FLIP: (OUTSIDE) Thanks Ana. I really feel the part in this getup.
FLIP: FOLLOWS HER IN.
ANA: You seem so much better. Ah. Here is my husband. Hard at work!
